    Water-Stable Metal–Organic Frameworks for Fast and High Dichromate Trapping via Single-Crystal-to-Single-Crystal Ion Exchange

    • Hong-Ru Fu†‡
      • , 
    • Zhong-Xuan Xu†
      • , and 
    • Jian Zhang*†
    View Author Information
    † State Key Laboratory of Structural Chemistry, Fujian Institute of Research on the Structure of Matter, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Fuzhou, Fujian, 350002, China
    ‡ University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, 100049, Beijing, P. R. China
    *E-mail: zhj@fjirsm.ac.cn (J.Z.).
    Cite this: Chem. Mater. 2015, 27, 1, 205–210
    Publication Date (Web):December 10, 2014

    Abstract

    Two metal–organic frameworks [Zn2(Tipa)2(OH)]·3NO3·12H2O (FIR-53, FIR denotes Fujian Institute of Research, Tipa = tris(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)phenyl)amine)) and [Zn(Tipa)]·2NO3·DMF·4H2O) (FIR-54) with large nanotubular channels were synthesized via Zn(II) ions coordinate the neutral Tipa ligand. The framework of FIR-53 contains 1D channels along the c axis with a cross section of 18 × 13 Å2. FIR-54 also consists of large channels with the 10.5 × 10.5 Å2 open windows. These porous materials efficiently trap Cr2O72– inorganic pollutant ions via the single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC-SC) approach. The Cr2O72– uptake capacities of FIR-53 and FIR-54 are high to 74.2 and 103 mg/g, respectively. Furthermore, the Cr2O72– trapping–releasing process of FIR-53 displays good regeneration. Meaningfully, the structure of FIR-53 after ion exchange can be accurately obtained by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, which further elaborates the SC-SC transformation.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Conclusion
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References
    Nowadays, water pollution is a global environmental issue, and considerable research attention has been paid to the removal of pollutants from wastewater. Various techniques have been introduced for the removal of inorganic metal ions, including ion exchange,(1) adsorption,(2) photocatalytic reduction, or degradation.(3) Commonly, ion exchange is regarded as a cost-effective and eco-friendly strategy since it usually offers several advantages in terms of sensitivity, selectivity, and simplicity of operation.(4) Generally, ion exchangers are divided into two categories: inorganic and organic types. Most inorganic ion exchangers, such as zeolites and layered double hydroxides, depend on small pore sizes for ionic exchange, and thus exchange kinetics is slow, as well as adsorption capacity is limited.(5) Although organic exchangers, such as sol–gel adsorbents and polymer resins, are rapid in exchange, they do not have excellent thermal and chemical stability like inorganic counterparts.(6) The development of higher-performance ion exchangers for water treatment is still challenge.
    As an emerging class of porous materials, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with high surface areas are built from metal ions or metal-based clusters linked by various organic bridging ligands.(7) The main advantage of MOFs over other microporous materials (e.g., zeolites or activated carbons) resides in the opportunity to control the pore surface properties, such as the precisely porous microenvironment, and tunable channel size.(8) The outstanding characters of MOFs should facilitate more chemical and physical properties, such as a host–guest system,(9) ion exchange,(10) and size-confinement effect for the adsorption of organic dyes.(11) These MOF materials have been expected to play a role as an important platform for the remediation of environmental problems.
    It is well-known that many of the metal pollutants as their oxo-hydroxo anionic forms (e.g., pertechnetate (TcO4–), arsenate (AsO43–), selenite (SeO32–, etc.) occur in water.(12) One of these priorities, chromate (CrO42– or Cr2O72–), is rapidly diffusing and a known carcinogen, occurring from metal-plating, leather-tanning, and other industries.(13) So far, to the best of our knowledge, only several cationic MOFs were reported to trap chromate or dichromate via ion exchange.(14-16) The uptake capacities of chromate or dichromate ions in these MOFs have potential to be improved, and the dichromate trapping processes for theses MOFs are rarely known from a single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC-SC) fashion.(16) To gain direct and accurate structural information, the SC-SC fashion is a preferable platform for the host–guest chemistry of adsorption and ion exchange.(17-19)
    Herein, we report two cationic MOFs with large nanotubular channels, [Zn2(Tipa)2(OH)]·3NO3·12H2O (FIR-53, FIR denotes Fujian Institute of Research, Tipa = tris(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)phenyl)amine)) and [Zn(Tipa)]·2NO3·DMF·4H2O (FIR-54), which show fast ion exchange and high uptake capacity for Cr2O72– through the SC-SC process.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Materials and Instrumentation

    The tris(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)phenyl)amine (Tipa) was prepared according to the literature method.(20) All other chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and were used without further purification. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were carried out with a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer Spectrum One spectrophotometer. All powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analyses were recorded on a MiniFlex-II diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) with a step size of 0.05°. Thermal stability studies were carried out on a NETSCHZ STA-449C thermoanalyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a N2 atmosphere. UV–vis adsorption spectra were collected on a PerkinElmer Lambda 35 spectrophotometer to monitor the exchange progress. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) measurement was performed on an Ultima-2 spectrometer.

    Synthesis of Tris(4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl)phenyl)amine (Tipa; Scheme 1)

    Tris(4-bromophenyl)amine (0.480 g, 1.0 mmol), imidazole (0.41 g, 6.0 mmol), K2CO3 (0.728 g, 6.0 mmol), and CuSO4 (0.01 g, 0.04 mmol) were mixed and heated at 120 °C for 48 h under a nitrogen atmosphere. The mixture was cooled to the room temperature, and was then washed with water. The solids were filtered and dried to give the light pale crude product. Final Tipa sample was recrystallized from this light pale crude product by using water and ethanol as solvent (Yield: 74%).

    Synthesis of FIR-53

    A mixture of Tipa (0.0225 g, 0.05 mmol), l-proline (0.0115 g, 0.10 mmol), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0560 g, 0.2 mmol), MeOH (8 mL), and NaOH (2 mL, 0.1 M) was heated in a 20 mL scintillation vial at 100 °C for 72 h, followed by cooling to room temperature. The resulting mixture was washed with methanol and water, and colorless block crystals were collected and dried in air (29.2 mg, 73% yield, based on Tipa ligand).

    Synthesis of FIR-54

    A mixture of Tipa (0.0225 g, 0.05 mmol), l-proline (0.0115 g, 0.10 mmol), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0560 g, 0.2 mmol), and DMF/MeOH/H2O (5 mL, v:v:v 3:1:1) was placed in a 20 mL scintillation vial at 100 °C for 12 h, followed by cooling to room temperature. The resulting mixture was washed with DMF and water, and colorless block crystals were collected and dried in air (38.4 mg, 64% yield, based on Tipa ligand).

    Synthesis of FIR-53-Cr2O7

    The crystals of as-synthesized FIR-53 (60 mg, 0.05 mmol) were immersed in a 20 mL 2 × 10–3 mol/L solution of K2Cr2O7 and kept for 6 days. After decanting the solution, the resultant orange-yellow crystals were washed thoroughly with deionized water and dried in air.

    Crystallographic Studies

    Suitable single crystals were carefully selected under an optical microscope and glued to thin glass fibers. Whereafter, single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses were performed on a computer-controlled SuperNova CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λMo–Kα = 0.71073 Å) and Cu Kα radiation (λCu–Kα = 1.54178 Å). The structures were solved using the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods on F2 by using the SHELX-97 program package.(21) The SQUEEZE option of PLATON(23) was used to eliminate the contribution of disordered guest molecules to the reflection intensities. The formulas of FIR-53 and FIR-54 were calculated by considering the results of thermogravimetric analysis, element analysis and single-crystal structures, respectively. The high R factor for FIR-53-Cr2O7 may be related to the disordered guests. Crystal data for FIR-53: monoclinic, a = 34.4789(9) Å, b = 29.8973(6) Å, c = 16.2075(4) Å, β = 109.005(2)°, V = 15796.4(7) Å3, T = 100(2) K, space group C2/c, Z = 8, 31 457 reflections measured, 16 150 independent reflections (Rint = 0.0344). The final R1 value was 0.0464 (I > 2σ(I)). The final wR(F2) value was 0.1353 (I > 2σ(I)). The final R1 value was 0.0591 (all data). The final wR(F2) value was 0.1441 (all data). The goodness of fit on F2 was 1.056. Crystal data for FIR-54: orthorhombic, a = 28.4095(12) Å, b = 28.0922(11) Å, c = 9.4743(5) Å, V = 7561.3(6) Å3, T = 100(2) K, space group Pnna, Z = 8, 18 175 reflections measured, 7761 independent reflections (Rint = 0.0512). The final R1 value was 0.0805 (I > 2σ(I)). The final wR(F2) value was 0.2377 (I > 2σ(I)). The final R1 value was 0.1057 (all data). The final wR(F2) value was 0.2657 (all data). The goodness of fit on F2 was 1.003. Crystal data for FIR-53-Cr2O7: monoclinic, a = 35.157(8) Å, b = 29.716(6) Å, c = 16.278(4) Å, β = 109.757(4)°, V = 16005(6) Å3, T = 100(2) K, space group C2/c, Z = 8, 63 658 reflections measured, 18 329 independent reflections (Rint = 0.0745). The final R1 value was 0.1085 (I > 2σ(I)). The final wR(F2) value was 0.3157 (I > 2σ(I)). The final R1 value was 0.1286 (all data). The final wR(F2) value was 0.3348 (all data). The goodness of fit on F2 was 1.175.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Conclusion
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References
    Single-crystal X-ray crystallography reveals that compound FIR-53 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c and features a double-(6,3)-layer structure. As shown in Figure 1a, in the structure of FIR-53, each Zn(II) center shows tetrahedral geometry and is coordinated by three N atoms from three Tipa ligands and one O atom from the μ2-OH group. Without the μ2-OH groups, the μ3-Tipa ligands link the Zn(II) centers into a (6,3)-layer along the ab plane. Two (6,3)-layers are further connected together by the μ2-OH groups to form a double layer (Figure 1b), and the resulting double layers are packing into a three-dimensional cationic [Zn2(Tipa)2(OH)]3+ framework with π–π interactions (3.850 Å, the distance between the centers of benzene rings) between adjacent layers. The overall [Zn2(Tipa)2(OH)]3+ framework shows 1D ellipse channels along the c axis (Figure 1c), and the window size for each channel is approximately 18 × 13 Å2 (taking the van der Waals radii into consideration). Although a large number of cationic MOFs have been reported, to the best of our knowledge, cationic MOFs with so large nanotubular channels are very rare.(22) Remarkably, two structurally ordered NO3– anions are presented in the asymmetric unit of FIR-53, and the third NO3– anion is disordered in the structure. The contribution of the disordered solvent molecules and NO3– anions was subtracted from the reflection data by the SQUEEZE method as implemented in PLATON program,(23) and a total of 41.6% of the accessible volume for FIR-53 was found.
    Unlike FIR-53, FIR-54 crystallizes in space group Pnna and exhibits a 3D open framework with 1D helix channels. In the structure of FIR-54, each Zn(II) center is tetrahedrally coordinated by three N atoms from three Tipa ligands and one O atom from the coordinated water molecule (Figure 2a). The μ3-Tipa ligands connect the Zn(II) centers into a cationic 3D framework with 3-connected utp topology (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). Notably, the Zn–Tipa connectivity generates equal right- and left-handed hexagonal helices in the network (Figure 2b). The 2-fold interpenetrating final framework still shows 1D channels with the 10.5 Å × 10.5 Å windows (Figure 2c). Given the charge-balance consideration, there are two NO3– ions per formula unit. However, the disordered ions and guest molecules are not well-defined. The effective free volume per unit cell volume, calculated by PLATON analyses, is 41.8% (3163.1 Å3 per unit) without consideration of the guest molecules and NO3– anions.
    Given that FIR-53 is a highly charged cationic layer structure, anion exchange for oxo-anion pollutants was studied and chromate was chosen as an initial model. The anion exchange was performed under ambient conditions by simply placing crystals of FIR-53 into the dichromate solution with 2 × 10–3 mol/L. The vials keep static after introducing 60 mg of dried FIR-53 into a 4 mL dichromate aqueous solution. (The molar ratio between FIR-53 and dichromate is about 1:2.) The resultant exchange solution was monitored by liquid UV–vis spectroscopy at intervals. The intensity of the main characteristic adsorption peak of Cr2O72– (257 nm) quickly decreased at the early stage, indicating that the Cr2O72– in solution promptly entered into the channels in FIR-53 by exchanging NO3–. As shown in Figure 3b, FIR-53 was submerged in 2 × 10–3 mol/L aqueous solution of K2Cr2O7, and the corresponding Cr2O72– concentration in solution decreased by 95% within only 10 min. No further decrease in dichromate concentration was detected after 1 h, indicating that the anion-exchange process was complete. Meanwhile, the color of the solid in the solution changed from colorless to yellow (Figure 3a), implying the existence of Cr2O72– in the solid. Noteworthily, single crystals retain their integrity throughout the exchange.
    Similar ion-exchange experiments on FIR-53 were further carried out in 4 × 10–3 and 6 × 10–3 mol/L solutions of K2Cr2O7, and 93.3% and 73.4% of the dichromate in the solution were uptaken by FIR-53 after 4 h, respectively. Subsequently, a slow decrease in Cr2O72– concentration was observed, and no further decrease in anion concentration was detected after 10 and 18 h. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) and UV–vis spectroscopy indicated that nearly 100% and 90% Cr2O72– were trapped into the channel of FIR-53 in 4 × 10–3 and 6 × 10–3 mol/L solutions of K2Cr2O7, respectively (Figure 3b). The total exchange capacity of FIR-53 for dichromate is 74.2 mg/g (the theoretically maximum dichromate capacity is 217.6 mg/g). In addition, the same experiments were carried out for FIR-54, and the similar adsorption trends were discovered as well as FIR-53 (Figures S4 and S5 in the Supporting Information). The overall adsorption capacity of FIR-54 for dichromate reaches up to 103 mg/g (Figure S7 in the Supporting Information) (the theoretically maximum dichromate capacity is 278.4 mg/g). It is worth mentioning that only limited cases have been reported of the exchange of Cr2O72– by cationic crystalline materials. For examples, 2-D compound, SLUG-21,(14) exhibited 60 mg/g exchange capacity for Cr2O72– after exchanging for 48 h, and 3-D Dy-based MOFs can capture 62.9 mg/g in 6 h.(24) The adsorption capacity of natural zeolites modified with hexadecylpyridinium bromide is 14.3 mg/g after 48 h (Table S1 in the Supporting Information).(25) Comparably, FIR-53 and FIR-54 exhibit high-capacity and high-efficient trapping of Cr2O72–.
    The release tests were carried out to evaluate the regeneration ability of the ion exchanger. For FIR-53, the samples were centrifuged, rinsed with water, and dried in air after being submerged in 2 × 10–3 mol/L dichromate solution for 3 days; then the solid was placed in the same volume solution in the presence of a 200-fold molar excess of nitrate. The UV–Vis measurement showed that the release efficiency of Cr2O72– was high up to 98% after 26 h (Figure 4a). Such a trapping and releasing process was performed for five continuous cycles; FIR-53 still retains approximately 87% release efficiency (Figure 4b). Generally, the release of the pollutant anions is more difficult due to the strong interactions between metal oxo anions and cationic framework. For example, SLUG-21 has the ability of rapid capture,(19) but reuse of the material is in fact undesirable. By contrast, FIR-53 displays much faster and more effective in the trapping–releasing processes.
    The reversibility of FIR-54 was also tested. Unlike FIR-53, there was almost no dichromate to be released in the 200-fold molar excess of nitrate solution. When 200-fold molar amounts of SO42– or ClO4– were used as the triggers, 27% and 91% of Cr2O72– were exchanged after 72 h, respectively. No further release was detected. In Na2ClO4 solution, the exchange efficiency dropped to 63% after five trapping–releasing cycles (Figure S6 in the Supporting Information).
    Equally important to capacity for anion trapping is selectivity. Given the high-capacity and rapid ion-exchange function of FIR-53, the selective adsorption was verified. The dried FIR-53 sample (120 mg) was immersed in a 10 mL solution containing mixed anions (Cl–, Br–, NO3–, Cr2O72–), with 0.01 mol/L of each, for 48 h. The UV–vis and ICP measurements indicated that the adsorption of Cr2O72– is not disturbed by other ions. Nevertheless, when the equal molar CO32– was added in the above solution, the uptake efficiency of Cr2O72– went down sharply to 17% or so, indicating that the CO32– ion is the strong competitor to Cr2O72– ion (Figure S8 in the Supporting Information). When the dried FIR-53 sample was immersed in a 10 mL solution containing mixed anions (Cl–, Br–, NO3– with a concentration of 0.10 mol/L or 0.40 mol/L, and Cr2O72– with a concentration of 0.01 mol/L) for 48 h, the adsorption of Cr2O72– was still at high efficiency. Once more, when the dried FIR-53 sample was immersed in the mixed solution (Cl–, Br–, NO3–, SO42–, ClO4– with a concentration of 0.10 mol/L of each, and Cr2O72– with a concentration of 0.01 mol/L), the ion-exchange efficiency of Cr2O72– drastically dropped (Figure S9 in the Supporting Information).
    UV–vis and ICP analyses revealed the existence and molar amount of Cr(VI). Meanwhile, the appearance of an IR characteristic adsorption coming from Cr2O72– at about 770 cm–1 and the disappearance of the broad band arising from NO3– at 1350 cm–1 were observed, also suggesting that Cr2O72– replaced NO3– into the channel of FIR-53 or FIR-54 (Figures S13 and S14 in the Supporting Information).(26) However, these characterization methods cannot supply a direct and accurate picture to show the structure containing the dichromate. Fortunately, the sample FIR-53 (or FIR-54) after ion exchange was subject to single-crystal X-ray diffraction, but only the structure of FIR-53 containing the guest anions was obtained. As shown in Figure 5, Cr2O72– anions fill into the channels to balance the framework charge, indicating that ion exchange occurred exactly via single-crystal-to- single-crystal transformation. It is also observed that Cr2O72– anions like NO3– anions are fixed into the double layer, and adjoin the edge of the large channel (Figure 5c,d). Moreover, weak C–H···O interactions between the framework and Cr2O72– anions were found (Table S2 in the Supporting Information). The phenomenon indicates that the anions can be easily exchanged, which need to go over very little resistance, and the large channel provides a fairly convenient passage for the diffusion of anions. These results can well explain that FIR-53 has the ability of the high-efficient ion exchange and excellent reversibility. More valuably, it demonstrates that the above adsorption capacity of Cr(VI) is correct through dichromate identified as the principal component.

    Conclusion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    • Abstract
    • Introduction
    • Experimental Section
    • Results and Discussion
    • Conclusion
    • Supporting Information
    • Acknowledgment
    • References
    In summary, two cationic MOFs (FIR-53 and FIR-54) consisting of nanotubular channels have been successfully prepared through the assembly of Zn2+ ions and neutral Tipa ligands. The large-scale channels of the frameworks of FIR-53 and FIR-54 provide a very convenient pathway for the diffusion capture of dichromate. FIR-54 has a high adsorption capacity for dichromate with an uptake value over 100 mg g–1. Particularly, FIR-53 and FIR-54 can trap Cr2O72– through SC-SC transformation with high capacity. It is worth mentioning that FIR-53 shows excellent reversibility and regeneration without losing its uptake capacity. The accurate structure after ionic exchange can be obtained via the mean of single-crystal X-ray diffraction, demonstrating that chromium Cr(VI) ion exists in the form of dichromate. This work provides an effective strategy for the design of the ion-exchange media by employing cationic MOFs with large channels, and will contribute a lot to the removal of toxic heavy-metal ions.

      "The Waters Were Made Sweet". Advances in Ion Exchange Technology
      Streat, Michael

      A review with many refs. of the progress in ion exchange technol. that has been made during the latter part of the twentieth century. The history of ion exchange is marked by many important milestones, notably the development of novel polymeric materials and considerable advances in our understanding of the underlying fundamental principles. Sep., there have been major advances in the design and development of the app. and equipment required to perform industrial ion exchange processes in a wide range of modern applications.

      Removal of C.I. Basic Blue 3 dye by sorption onto cation exchange resin, functionalized and non-functionalized polymeric sorbents from aqueous solutions and wastewaters
      Wawrzkiewicz, Monika
      Chemical Engineering Journal (Amsterdam, Netherlands) (2013), 217 (), 414-425CODEN: CMEJAJ; ISSN:1385-8947. (Elsevier B.V.)
      The adsorption behavior of the cationic dye C. I. Basic Blue 3 (BB3) from aq. soln. on the cation exchanger Lewatit MonoPlus SP 112 (SP 112), functionalized Dowex Optipore SD 2 (SD 2) and non-functionalized Amberlite XAD 1180 (XAD 1180) polymeric sorbents was investigated to identify the ability of these materials to remove textile dye from wastewaters. For this purpose a series of batch tests were carried out as a function of contact time (1 min-96 h), dye concn. (100, 500, 1000 mg/L), auxiliaries presence (NaCl, Na2SO4, surfactants) and adsorption temp. (20-50°). Total decolorization of basic dyes wastewater by SP 112 occurred after 1 h. Dye desorption from the cation exchanger reached 100% in four cycles of sorption-desorption using 1 M HCl in 90% CH3OH. The working ion exchange capacities calcd. from the breakthrough curves were equal to 205 mg/mL for SP 112, 3.5 mg/mL for SD 2 and 6.5 mg/mL for XAD 1180.       Stoichiometry of Removal of Natural Organic Matter by Ion Exchange
      Boyer, Treavor H.; Singer, Philip C.
      Environmental Science & Technology (2008), 42 (2), 608-613CODEN: ESTHAG; ISSN:0013-936X. (American Chemical Society)
      Five anion exchange resins, including a magnetic ion exchange (MIEX) resin, were evaluated to remove Suwannee River Fulvic Acid (SRFA) in the presence of HCO3- and Cl-. SRFA charge d., obtained by potentiometric titrn., was used to perform charge balances for ion exchange reactions involving SRFA, HCO3-, and Cl- under different soln. conditions. Results clearly showed the equivalence of SRFA uptake and Cl- release by ion exchange. Although anion exchange resin structure did not affect reaction stoichiometry, polyacrylic resins exhibited greater SRFA removal than polystyrene resins. The hindered SRFA removal by polystyrene resins was hypothesized to be due to size exclusion. The MIEX resin, which has a polyacrylic structure, performed similarly to the other polyacrylic resins: the sepn. factor for SRFA over Cl- was ∼8 times greater than for HCO3- over Cl-. Results provided an improved understanding of interactions among natural org. matter (NOM), inorg. anions, and anion exchange resins, and should result in more effective applications of ion exchange to remove NOM for drinking water treatment.

      Parasuraman, Deepika; Sarker, Avijeet K.; Serpe, Michael J.

Initial observations showed that the aggregates composed of microgels with large diam. yielded improved uptake efficiency over the aggregates composed of small diam. microgels. Langmuir sorption isotherms were fit to the data for the dye removal by the unaggregated and aggregated microgels, which showed good fits in all cases.

More research is needed to find the practical utility of low-cost adsorbents on com. scale.

      Heavy Metal Uptake by Lignin: Comparison of Biotic Ligand Models with an Ion-Exchange Process
      Crist, Ray H.; Martin, J. Robert; Crist, DeLanson R.
      Environmental Science and Technology (2002), 36 (7), 1485-1490CODEN: ESTHAG; ISSN:0013-936X. (American Chemical Society)
      Metal uptake by kraft lignin, hereafter referred to as lignin, occurs by displacement of protons or bound metals with equil. consts. KexH and Kex, resp. Values calcd. for wide ranges of initial concns. are reasonably const., thereby demonstrating the validity of these displacement processes and proving that uptake in these systems is not simple adsorption. It was found that the stoichiometry for Sr and Cd uptake by Ca-loaded lignin is 1 mol of metal for 1 mol of Ca released. This observation for metals of very different binding strengths is difficult to rationalize with the biotic ligand model as generally applied but is in complete agreement with an ion-exchange process. Binding strengths to lignin, which contains only oxygen ligands, follow the order Pb > Cu > Zn > Cd > Ca (strongest to weakest). For proton displacement, only more tightly bound metals such as Pb, Cu, Zn, and Cd can compete with protons for anionic binding sites at low pH, but at high pH, uptake of Ca, Sr, and Li can occur. An obsd. logarithmic decrease of KexH with pH can be explained by having only weaker acids available for proton displacement under more basic conditions. The advantages and disadvantages of using adsorption and biotic ligand models for an ion-exchange process are discussed.

      A strategy based on reticulating metal ions and org. carboxylate links into extended networks has been advanced to a point that allowed the design of porous structures in which pore size and functionality could be varied systematically.       Design and synthesis of metal-organic frameworks using metal-organic polyhedra as supermolecular building blocks
      Perry, John J., IV; Perman, Jason A.; Zaworotko, Michael J.
      Chemical Society Reviews (2009), 38 (5), 1400-1417CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      This crit. review highlights supermol. building blocks (SBBs) in the context of their impact upon the design, synthesis, and structure of metal-org. materials (MOMs). MOMs, also known as coordination polymers, hybrid inorg.-org. materials, and metal-org. frameworks, represent an emerging class of materials that have attracted the imagination of solid-state chemists because MOMs combine unprecedented levels of porosity with a range of other functional properties that occur through the metal moiety and/or the org. ligand.       Selective anion exchange with nanogated isoreticular positive metal-organic frameworks
      Zhao Xiang; Bu Xianhui; Wu Tao; Zheng Shou-Tian; Wang Le; Feng Pingyun

      Crystalline porous materials, especially inorganic porous solids such as zeolites, usually have negative frameworks with extra-framework mobile cations and are widely used for cation exchange.       Metal-Organic Frameworks and Self-Assembled Supramolecular Coordination Complexes: Comparing and Contrasting the Design, Synthesis, and Functionality of Metal-Organic Materials
      Cook, Timothy R.; Zheng, Yao-Rong; Stang, Peter J.
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2013), 113 (1), 734-777CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. In recent decades, two new branches of coordination chem. have emerged, metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) and supramol. coordination complexes (SCCs). The former are comprised of infinite networks of metal centers or inorg. clusters bridged by simple org. linkers through metal-ligand coordination bonds. The latter encompass discrete systems in which carefully selected metal centers undergo self-assembly with ligands contg. multiple binding sites oriented with specific angularity to generate a finite supramol. complex. On the most basic level, both SCCs and MOFs share the design of metal nodes linked by org. ligands and such constructs can be broadly defined as metal-org. materials (MOMs). This review is intended to illustrate the commonalities in design, building blocks, and applications while also pointing out how and why the chem. of MOFs and SCCs is unique.

      A New Paradigm for Anion Trapping in High Capacity and Selectivity: Crystal-to-Crystal Transformation of Cationic Materials
      Fei, Honghan; Bresler, Marc R.; Oliver, Scott R. J.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2011), 133 (29), 11110-11113CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      We describe a new methodol. to the selective trapping of priority pollutants that occur inherently as oxo-anions (e.g., perchlorate, chromate, arsenate, pertechnetate, etc.) or org. anions (e.g., salicylate, pharmaceuticals, and their metabolites, which are often chlorinated into potentially more harmful compds.). The typical approach to trapping anions is exchange into cationic hosts such as resins or layered double hydroxides. Both capacity and selectivity are limited by the equil. of the process and moreover are often subject to interference, e.g., by carbonate that is always present in water from atm. CO2.       Guest Exchange through Single Crystal-Single Crystal Transformations in a Flexible Hydrogen-Bonded Framework
      Xiao, Wenchang; Hu, Chunhua; Ward, Michael D.
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2014), 136 (40), 14200-14206CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      A mol. framework based on guanidinium cations and 1,2,4,5-tetra(4-sulfonatophenyl)benzene (TSPB), an arom. tetrasulfonate with nominal 2-fold and mirror symmetry, exhibits three crystallog. unique 1-dimensional channels as a consequence of mol. symmetry and complementary H bonding between the guanidinium (G) ions and the sulfonate (S) groups of TSPB. Unlike previous GS frameworks, this new topol. is sufficiently flexible to permit reversible release and adsorption of guest mols. in large single crystals through a cyclic shrinkage and expansion of the channels with retention of single crystallinity, as verified by single crystal x-ray diffraction. Also, the G4TSPB framework permits guest exchange between various guest mols. through SCSCTs as well as exchange discrimination based on the size and character of the three different channels. The exchange of guest mols. during single crystal-single crystal transformations (SCSCT), a rare occurrence for H-bonded frameworks, is rather fast, with diffusivities of ∼10-6 cm2 s-1. Rapid diffusion in the two channels having cross sections sufficient to accommodate two guest mols. can be explained by two-way or ring diffusion, most likely vacancy assisted. Surprisingly, rapid guest exchange also is obsd. in a smaller channel having a cross-section that accommodates only one guest mol., which can only be explained by guest-assisted single-file unidirectional diffusion. Several single crystals of inclusion compds. can be realized only through guest exchange in the intact framework, suggesting an approach to the synthesis of single cryst. inclusion compds. that otherwise cannot be attained through direct crystn. methods.

      A short history of SHELX
      Sheldrick, George M.

      An account is given of the development of the SHELX system of computer programs from SHELX-76 to the present day. In addn. to identifying useful innovations that have come into general use through their implementation in SHELX, a crit. anal. is presented of the less-successful features, missed opportunities and desirable improvements for future releases of the software. SHELXL is the most widely used program for small-mol. refinement and SHELXS and SHELXD are often employed for structure soln. despite the availability of objectively superior programs. SHELXL also finds a niche for the refinement of macromols. against high-resoln. or twinned data; SHELXPRO acts as an interface for macromol. applications. SHELXC, SHELXD and SHELXE are proving useful for the exptl. phasing of macromols., esp. because they are fast and robust and so are often employed in pipelines for high-throughput phasing. This paper could serve as a general literature citation when one or more of the open-source SHELX programs (and the Bruker AXS version SHELXTL) are employed in the course of a crystal-structure detn.

      Spek, Anthony L.
      Acta Crystallographica, Section D: Biological Crystallography (2009), 65 (2), 148-155CODEN: ABCRE6; ISSN:0907-4449. (International Union of Crystallography)
      A review. Automated structure validation was introduced in chem. crystallog. about 12 years ago as a tool to assist practitioners with the exponential growth in crystal structure analyses. Validation has since evolved into an easy-to-use checkCIF/PLATON web-based IUCr service. The result of a crystal structure detn. has to be supplied as a CIF-formatted computer-readable file. In addn., the reported structure is checked for incomplete anal., errors in the anal., and relevant issues to be verified. Structure validation has largely eliminated obvious problems with structure reports published in IUCr journals, such as refinement in a space group of too low symmetry. This paper reports on the current status of structure validation and possible future extensions.

      Microhydration of NO3-: A Theoretical Study on Structure, Stability and IR Spectra
      Pathak, A. K.; Mukherjee, T.; Maity, D. K.
      Journal of Physical Chemistry A (2008), 112 (15), 3399-3408CODEN: JPCAFH; ISSN:1089-5639. (American Chemical Society)
      A systematic study on the structure and stability of nitrate anion hydrated clusters, NO3-·nH2O (n = 1-8) were carried out using the DFT-B3LYP method. Several possible initial structures are considered for each size cluster to locate equil. geometry by applying a correlated hybrid d. functional with 6-311++G(d,p) basis function. Three different types of arrangements, namely, sym. double hydrogen bonding, single hydrogen bonding and inter-water hydrogen bonding are obtained in these hydrated clusters. Up to five solvent H2O mols. can stay around solute NO3- anion in structures having an inter-water hydrogen-bonded cyclic network. A linear correlation is obtained for weighted av. solvent stabilization energy with the size (n) of the hydrated cluster. Distinctly different shifts of IR bands are obsd. in these hydrated clusters for different kinds of bonding environments of O-H and N=O stretching modes compared to isolated H2O and NO3- anion. Weighted av. IR spectra are calcd. on the basis of statistical population of individual configurations of each size cluster at 150 K.

        Transmetalation: routes to metal exchange within metal-organic frameworks
        Lalonde, Marianne; Bury, Wojciech; Karagiaridi, Olga; Brown, Zachary; Hupp, Joseph T.; Farha, Omar K.
        Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2013), 1 (18), 5453-5468CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. The present work is a crit. review of metal exchange (transmetalation) involving metal nodes and metalated struts in metal-org. frameworks. Particular emphasis is given to drawing parallels between different examples of transmetalation in order to understand the influence of coordination environment, solvents, nature of the metals and other variables on the process. We hope that the present review will be of use to those involved in the incorporation of various metal centers to create isostructural MOFs and study their properties.

        Removal of C.I. Basic Blue 3 dye by sorption onto cation exchange resin, functionalized and non-functionalized polymeric sorbents from aqueous solutions and wastewaters
        Wawrzkiewicz, Monika
        Chemical Engineering Journal (Amsterdam, Netherlands) (2013), 217 (), 414-425CODEN: CMEJAJ; ISSN:1385-8947. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The adsorption behavior of the cationic dye C. I. Basic Blue 3 (BB3) from aq. soln. on the cation exchanger Lewatit MonoPlus SP 112 (SP 112), functionalized Dowex Optipore SD 2 (SD 2) and non-functionalized Amberlite XAD 1180 (XAD 1180) polymeric sorbents was investigated to identify the ability of these materials to remove textile dye from wastewaters. For this purpose a series of batch tests were carried out as a function of contact time (1 min-96 h), dye concn. (100, 500, 1000 mg/L), auxiliaries presence (NaCl, Na2SO4, surfactants) and adsorption temp. (20-50°). The adsorption capacity (Q0) detd. from the Langmuir isotherm model at 20° was 560.7 mg/g for SP 112, 270.9 mg/g for SD 2 and 35.7 mg/g for XAD 1180. Q0 increased with the temp. rise for the cation exchanger and non-functionalized polymeric sorbent. The inverse effect of the temp. on BB3 sorption on SD 2 was obsd. Kinetic studies of the dye followed the pseudo-second order model rather than the pseudo-first order or intraparticle diffusion model. Total decolorization of basic dyes wastewater by SP 112 occurred after 1 h. Dye desorption from the cation exchanger reached 100% in four cycles of sorption-desorption using 1 M HCl in 90% CH3OH. The working ion exchange capacities calcd. from the breakthrough curves were equal to 205 mg/mL for SP 112, 3.5 mg/mL for SD 2 and 6.5 mg/mL for XAD 1180. These sorption properties of the polystyrene cation exchange resin Lewatit MonoPlus SP 112 recommend it as effective sorbent in the removal of org. ionic species like BB3 dye from aq. solns. and industrial wastewaters.

        Stoichiometry of Removal of Natural Organic Matter by Ion Exchange
        Boyer, Treavor H.; Singer, Philip C.
        Environmental Science & Technology (2008), 42 (2), 608-613CODEN: ESTHAG; ISSN:0013-936X. (American Chemical Society)
        Five anion exchange resins, including a magnetic ion exchange (MIEX) resin, were evaluated to remove Suwannee River Fulvic Acid (SRFA) in the presence of HCO3- and Cl-. SRFA charge d., obtained by potentiometric titrn., was used to perform charge balances for ion exchange reactions involving SRFA, HCO3-, and Cl- under different soln. conditions. Results clearly showed the equivalence of SRFA uptake and Cl- release by ion exchange. Although anion exchange resin structure did not affect reaction stoichiometry, polyacrylic resins exhibited greater SRFA removal than polystyrene resins. The hindered SRFA removal by polystyrene resins was hypothesized to be due to size exclusion. The MIEX resin, which has a polyacrylic structure, performed similarly to the other polyacrylic resins: the sepn. factor for SRFA over Cl- was ∼8 times greater than for HCO3- over Cl-. Results provided an improved understanding of interactions among natural org. matter (NOM), inorg. anions, and anion exchange resins, and should result in more effective applications of ion exchange to remove NOM for drinking water treatment.

        Sorption of Organic Compounds, Oxyanions, and Heavy Metal Ions on Surfactant Modified Titanate Nanotubes
        Chao, Huan-Ping; Lee, Chung-Kung; Juang, Lain-Chuen; Han, Yin-Lung
        Industrial & Engineering Chemistry Research (2013), 52 (29), 9843-9850CODEN: IECRED; ISSN:0888-5885. (American Chemical Society)
        The adsorption capacities and mechanisms of org. compds. with water solubilities (Sw) ranging from 55 to 75,000 mg/L, oxyanions, and heavy metal ions onto surfactant (hexadecyltrimethylammonium, HDTMA)-modified titanate nanotubes (TNT) have been investigated. Effects of the HDTMA-modified process on the revolution of microstructures and surface chem. characteristics of TNT were characterized with SEM, transmission electron microscopy, nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms, Fourier transform IR spectroscopy, and ζ potential. The adsorption isotherms of selected adsorbates on the HDTMA-modified TNT (HMTNT) were measured to understand the effects of the surfactant-modified process on the adsorption properties of TNT. The HMTNT possessed both hydrophilic and hydrophobic surfaces to uptake org. compds. with various Sw values. Since the hydrophobic bonding by conglomeration of large C16 alkyl groups assocd. with HDTMA could render a pos. charge development on the surface of TNT, HMTNT could simultaneously adsorb the oxyanions (on the surface covered by HDTMA) and heavy metal ions (on the surface not covered by HDTMA) through the anion and cation exchange mechanisms, resp. The HMTNT might be regarded as an amphiphilic and dual-electronic adsorbent, which could effectively remove many different kinds of contaminants. The regeneration of HMTNT is briefly discussed.

        Poly(N-Isopropylacrylamide)-Based Microgels and Their Assemblies for Organic-Molecule Removal from Water
        Parasuraman, Deepika; Sarker, Avijeet K.; Serpe, Michael J.
        ChemPhysChem (2012), 13 (10), 2507-2515CODEN: CPCHFT; ISSN:1439-4235. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review is given on the use of poly(N-isopropylacrylamide)-co-acrylic acid (pNIPAm-co-AAc) microgels and their assemblies for the removal of an azo-dye mol., Orange II, from aq. solns. The ability of dispersed, single microgels to remove Orange II from aq. solns. at room temp. is discussed. Uptake efficiency (i.e., the amt. of Orange II removed from water) increased with AAc compn. in the microgels, yielding a max. uptake efficiency of 29.5% for pNIPAm microgels with 10% AAc. Assemblies of microgels (aggregates) were also investigated for their removal efficiency, which yielded a max. uptake efficiency of 44.1% at room temp. Removal efficiencies for the microgels and their aggregates were also monitored at elevated temps., and a max. of 56.6% removal efficiency was achieved for unaggregated microgels, while aggregates were able to remove 73.1% Orange II. To further explore the impact of the microgel system's structure on function, we studied the role microgel size in the aggregates plays on the uptake efficiency. Initial observations showed that the aggregates composed of microgels with large diam. yielded improved uptake efficiency over the aggregates composed of small diam. microgels. Langmuir sorption isotherms were fit to the data for the dye removal by the unaggregated and aggregated microgels, which showed good fits in all cases.

        Sacrificial template-directed synthesis of mesoporous magnesium oxide architectures with superior performance for organic dye adsorption
        Ai, Lunhong; Yue, Haitao; Jiang, Jing
        Nanoscale (2012), 4 (17), 5401-5408CODEN: NANOHL; ISSN:2040-3372. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Mesoporous MgO architectures were successfully synthesized by the direct thermal transformation of the sacrificial oxalate template. The as-prepd. mesoporous architectures were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electronic microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), X-ray energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), Fourier transform IR spectroscopy (FTIR), and nitrogen adsorption-desorption techniques. The MgO architectures showed extraordinary adsorption capacity and rapid adsorption rate for removal of Congo red (CR) from water. The max. adsorption capacity of the MgO architectures toward CR reached 689.7 mg g-1, much higher than most of the previously reported hierarchical adsorbents. The CR removal process was found to obey the Langmuir adsorption model and its kinetics followed pseudo-second-order rate equation. The superior adsorption performance of the mesoporous MgO architectures could be attributed to the unique mesoporous structure, high sp. surface area as well as strong electrostatic interaction.

        One-dimensional hierarchical heterostructures of In2S3 nanosheets on electrospun TiO2 nanofibers with enhanced visible photocatalytic activity
        Zhang, Xin; Li, Xinghua; Shao, Changlu; Li, Jinhuan; Zhang, Mingyi; Zhang, Peng; Wang, Kexin; Lu, Na; Liu, Yichun
        Journal of Hazardous Materials (2013), 260 (), 892-900CODEN: JHMAD9; ISSN:0304-3894. (Elsevier B.V.)
        In2S3 nanosheets were assembled on electrospun TiO2 nanofibers template by a hydrothermal technique. For the obtained one-dimensional In2S3/TiO2 hierarchical heterostructures (1D In2S3/TiO2 H-HSs), the d. and size of the secondary In2S3 nanosheets could be controlled by adjusting the reactant concns. for the prepn. of In2S3 in the hydrothermal process. The 1D In2S3/TiO2 H-HSs exhibited higher visible-light photocatalytic activity for the degrdn. of Methyl orange (MO) and the redn. of Cr(VI), as compared with the pure TiO2 nanofibers and pure In2S3 nanosheets. The enhanced visible light photocatalytic activity might be attributed to the extended absorption in the visible light region from the narrow band-gap In2S3, the effective photogenerated electron-hole sepn. by the photosynergistic effects of the In2S3/TiO2 H-HSs and quick electron-transfer in the 1D TiO2 nanofibers. Meanwhile, the 1D In2S3/TiO2 H-HSs could be recycled easily by sedimentation due to their nanofibrous nonwoven web structure. Moreover, the mechanisms of photodegrdn. of MO and photoredn. of Cr(VI) were proposed through systematical investigations. This work provided new insights into utilizing 1D In2S3/TiO2 H-HSs as high efficiency visible-light-driven photocatalysts for environmental remediation and energy conversion.

        Solar photocatalysis as a tertiary treatment to remove emerging pollutants from wastewater treatment plant effluents
        Bernabeu, A.; Vercher, R. F.; Santos-Juanes, L.; Simon, P. J.; Lardin, C.; Martinez, M. A.; Vicente, J. A.; Gonzalez, R.; Llosa, C.; Arques, A.; Amat, A. M.

        Water taken from the outlet of a wastewater treatment plant from the South East of Spain was treated by TiO2-based solar photocatalysis.         A review is given. Adsorption process has been proven one of the best water treatment technologies around the world and activated C is undoubtedly considered as universal adsorbent for the removal of diverse types of pollutants from water. Attempts have been made to develop inexpensive adsorbents utilizing numerous agro-industrial and municipal waste materials. More research is needed to find the practical utility of low-cost adsorbents on com. scale.

        Disinfection by-product formation of natural organic matter surrogates and treatment by coagulation, MIEX and nanofiltration
        Bond, T.; Goslan, E. H.; Parsons, S. A.; Jefferson, B.
        Water Research (2010), 44 (5), 1645-1653CODEN: WATRAG; ISSN:0043-1354. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Potentially the most effective means of controlling disinfection byproducts (DBPs) is to remove precursors before disinfection.         Heavy Metal Uptake by Lignin: Comparison of Biotic Ligand Models with an Ion-Exchange Process
        Crist, Ray H.; Martin, J. Robert; Crist, DeLanson R.
        Environmental Science and Technology (2002), 36 (7), 1485-1490CODEN: ESTHAG; ISSN:0013-936X. (American Chemical Society)
        Metal uptake by kraft lignin, hereafter referred to as lignin, occurs by displacement of protons or bound metals with equil. consts. KexH and Kex, resp. Values calcd. for wide ranges of initial concns. are reasonably const., thereby demonstrating the validity of these displacement processes and proving that uptake in these systems is not simple adsorption. It was found that the stoichiometry for Sr and Cd uptake by Ca-loaded lignin is 1 mol of metal for 1 mol of Ca released. This observation for metals of very different binding strengths is difficult to rationalize with the biotic ligand model as generally applied but is in complete agreement with an ion-exchange process. Binding strengths to lignin, which contains only oxygen ligands, follow the order Pb > Cu > Zn > Cd > Ca (strongest to weakest). For proton displacement, only more tightly bound metals such as Pb, Cu, Zn, and Cd can compete with protons for anionic binding sites at low pH, but at high pH, uptake of Ca, Sr, and Li can occur. An obsd. logarithmic decrease of KexH with pH can be explained by having only weaker acids available for proton displacement under more basic conditions. The advantages and disadvantages of using adsorption and biotic ligand models for an ion-exchange process are discussed.

        Insight into removal kinetic and mechanisms of anionic dye by calcined clay materials and lime
        Vimonses, Vipasiri; Jin, Bo; Chow, Christopher W. K.
        Journal of Hazardous Materials (2010), 177 (1-3), 420-427CODEN: JHMAD9; ISSN:0304-3894. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Recent work reported that a mixed adsorbent with natural clay materials and lime demonstrated an enhanced capacity and efficiency to remove anionic Congo Red dye from wastewater. This study aims to investigate the removal kinetic and mechanisms of the mixed materials involved in the decolorisation of the dye to maximize their prospective applications for industrial wastewater treatment. Dye removal was governed by combined physiochem. reactions of adsorption, ion-exchange, and pptn. Ca-dye pptn. contributed >70% total dye removal, followed by adsorption and ion-exchange. The dye removal kinetic followed the pseudo-second-order expression and was well described by the Freundlich isotherm model. This study indicated pH was a key parameter to govern the removal mechanisms, i.e. adsorption/coagulation at acidic pH and pptn. at basic condition. Yet, the overall removal efficiency was found to be independent to the operation conditions, resulting in >94% dye removal. This work revealed that the mixed clays and lime can be applied as alternative low-cost adsorbents for industrial wastewater treatment.

        Metal-Organic Frameworks and Self-Assembled Supramolecular Coordination Complexes: Comparing and Contrasting the Design, Synthesis, and Functionality of Metal-Organic Materials
        Cook, Timothy R.; Zheng, Yao-Rong; Stang, Peter J.
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2013), 113 (1), 734-777CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. In recent decades, two new branches of coordination chem. have emerged, metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) and supramol. coordination complexes (SCCs). The former are comprised of infinite networks of metal centers or inorg. clusters bridged by simple org. linkers through metal-ligand coordination bonds. The latter encompass discrete systems in which carefully selected metal centers undergo self-assembly with ligands contg. multiple binding sites oriented with specific angularity to generate a finite supramol. complex. On the most basic level, both SCCs and MOFs share the design of metal nodes linked by org. ligands and such constructs can be broadly defined as metal-org. materials (MOMs). This review is intended to illustrate the commonalities in design, building blocks, and applications while also pointing out how and why the chem. of MOFs and SCCs is unique.

        A New Paradigm for Anion Trapping in High Capacity and Selectivity: Crystal-to-Crystal Transformation of Cationic Materials
        Fei, Honghan; Bresler, Marc R.; Oliver, Scott R. J.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2011), 133 (29), 11110-11113CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        We describe a new methodol. to the selective trapping of priority pollutants that occur inherently as oxo-anions (e.g., perchlorate, chromate, arsenate, pertechnetate, etc.) or org. anions (e.g., salicylate, pharmaceuticals, and their metabolites, which are often chlorinated into potentially more harmful compds.). Both capacity and selectivity are limited by the equil. of the process and moreover are often subject to interference, e.g., by carbonate that is always present in water from atm. CO2. Our approach takes advantage of the metastability of our cationically charged materials to instead trap by recrystn. to a new structure. Exceptionally high adsorption capacities for permanganate and perrhenate, studied as models for pertechnetate, were found for a Ag(I)-based cationic extended framework. The exchange capacity reached 292 and 602 mg/g, resp., >5 times the exchange capacity compared to conventional layered double hydroxides. Our cationic material can also selectively trap these and other toxic oxo-anions when nontoxic anions (e.g., nitrate, carbonate) were present in an over 100-fold excess concn.

        Reversible Anion Exchange and Catalytic Properties of Two Cationic Metal-Organic Frameworks Based on Cu(I) and Ag(I)
        Fei, Honghan; Rogow, David L.; Oliver, Scott R. J.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2010), 132 (20), 7202-7209CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        We report the synthesis and characterization of two Ag(I)/Cu(I)-based cationic metal-org. frameworks and their application in both heterogeneous catalysis and anion exchange. The Cu(I)-based material was designed from our previously reported Ag(I) cationic topol. Both structures consist of cationic layers with π-π stacked chains of alternating metal and 4,4'-bipyridine. α,ω-Alkanedisulfonate serves as an anionic template, electrostatically bonding to the cationic layers. A comparative study on the influence of structure vs. size selectivity and reusability for both exchange and catalysis is discussed. Application to wastewater treatment is indicated.

        Guest Exchange through Single Crystal-Single Crystal Transformations in a Flexible Hydrogen-Bonded Framework
        Xiao, Wenchang; Hu, Chunhua; Ward, Michael D.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2014), 136 (40), 14200-14206CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A mol. framework based on guanidinium cations and 1,2,4,5-tetra(4-sulfonatophenyl)benzene (TSPB), an arom. tetrasulfonate with nominal 2-fold and mirror symmetry, exhibits three crystallog. unique 1-dimensional channels as a consequence of mol. symmetry and complementary H bonding between the guanidinium (G) ions and the sulfonate (S) groups of TSPB. Unlike previous GS frameworks, this new topol. is sufficiently flexible to permit reversible release and adsorption of guest mols. in large single crystals through a cyclic shrinkage and expansion of the channels with retention of single crystallinity, as verified by single crystal x-ray diffraction. Also, the G4TSPB framework permits guest exchange between various guest mols. through SCSCTs as well as exchange discrimination based on the size and character of the three different channels. The exchange of guest mols. during single crystal-single crystal transformations (SCSCT), a rare occurrence for H-bonded frameworks, is rather fast, with diffusivities of ∼10-6 cm2 s-1. Rapid diffusion in the two channels having cross sections sufficient to accommodate two guest mols. can be explained by two-way or ring diffusion, most likely vacancy assisted. Surprisingly, rapid guest exchange also is obsd. in a smaller channel having a cross-section that accommodates only one guest mol., which can only be explained by guest-assisted single-file unidirectional diffusion. Several single crystals of inclusion compds. can be realized only through guest exchange in the intact framework, suggesting an approach to the synthesis of single cryst. inclusion compds. that otherwise cannot be attained through direct crystn. methods.

        A short history of SHELX
        Sheldrick, George M.
        Acta Crystallographica, Section A: Foundations of Crystallography (2008), 64 (1), 112-122CODEN: ACACEQ; ISSN:0108-7673. (International Union of Crystallography)
        An account is given of the development of the SHELX system of computer programs from SHELX-76 to the present day. In addn. to identifying useful innovations that have come into general use through their implementation in SHELX, a crit. anal. is presented of the less-successful features, missed opportunities and desirable improvements for future releases of the software. An attempt is made to understand how a program originally designed for photog. intensity data, punched cards and computers over 10000 times slower than an av. modern personal computer has managed to survive for so long. SHELXL is the most widely used program for small-mol. refinement and SHELXS and SHELXD are often employed for structure soln. despite the availability of objectively superior programs. SHELXL also finds a niche for the refinement of macromols. against high-resoln. or twinned data; SHELXPRO acts as an interface for macromol. applications. SHELXC, SHELXD and SHELXE are proving useful for the exptl. phasing of macromols., esp. because they are fast and robust and so are often employed in pipelines for high-throughput phasing. This paper could serve as a general literature citation when one or more of the open-source SHELX programs (and the Bruker AXS version SHELXTL) are employed in the course of a crystal-structure detn.

        (a) Jiang, J. W.; Babarao, R.; Hu, Z. Q. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2011, 40, 3599– 3612
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        22a
        Molecular simulations for energy, environmental and pharmaceutical applications of nanoporous materials: from zeolites, metal-organic frameworks to protein crystals
        Jiang, Jianwen; Babarao, Ravichandar; Hu, Zhongqiao
        Chemical Society Reviews (2011), 40 (7), 3599-3612CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Nanoporous materials have widespread applications in chem. industry, but the pathway from lab. synthesis and testing to practical utilization of nanoporous materials is substantially challenging and requires fundamental understanding from the bottom up. With ever-growing computational resources, mol. simulations have become an indispensable tool for material characterization, screening and design. This tutorial review summarizes the recent simulation studies in zeolites, metal-org. frameworks and protein crystals, and provides a mol. overview for energy, environmental and pharmaceutical applications of nanoporous materials with increasing degree of complexity in building blocks. It is demonstrated that mol.-level studies can bridge the gap between phys. and engineering sciences, unravel microscopic insights that are otherwise exptl. inaccessible, and assist in the rational design of new materials. The review is concluded with major challenges in future simulation exploration of novel nanoporous materials for emerging applications.

        (b) Nouar, F.; Eckert, J.; Eubank, J. F.; Forster, P.; Eddaoudi, M. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2009, 131, 2864– 2866
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        22b
        Zeolite-like Metal-Organic Frameworks (ZMOFs) as Hydrogen Storage Platform: Lithium and Magnesium Ion-Exchange and H2-(rho-ZMOF) Interaction Studies
        Nouar, Farid; Eckert, Juergen; Eubank, Jarrod F.; Forster, Paul; Eddaoudi, Mohamed
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (8), 2864-2870CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Zeolite-like metal-org. frameworks (ZMOFs) are anionic, have readily exchangeable extra-framework cations, and can be constructed with a variety of org. linkers. ZMOFs therefore can be regarded as an excellent platform for systematic studies of the effect(s) of various structural factors on H2 binding/interaction with porous metal-org. materials. We find that the enhanced binding of mol. hydrogen in ion-exchanged ZMOFs with an anionic framework is largely governed by the presence of the electrostatic field in the cavity, which is reflected by isosteric heats of adsorption in these compds. which are greater by as much as 50% relative to those in neutral MOFs. Direct contact of the sorbed hydrogen with the exchangeable cations is shown not to be possible in the explored systems thus far, as they retain their form as aqua complexes.

        Spek, A. Acta Crystallogr., Sect. D 2009, 65, 148– 155
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Structure validation in chemical crystallography
        Spek, Anthony L.
        Acta Crystallographica, Section D: Biological Crystallography (2009), 65 (2), 148-155CODEN: ABCRE6; ISSN:0907-4449. (International Union of Crystallography)
        A review. Automated structure validation was introduced in chem. crystallog. about 12 years ago as a tool to assist practitioners with the exponential growth in crystal structure analyses. Validation has since evolved into an easy-to-use checkCIF/PLATON web-based IUCr service. The result of a crystal structure detn. has to be supplied as a CIF-formatted computer-readable file. The checking software tests the data in the CIF for completeness, quality, and consistency. In addn., the reported structure is checked for incomplete anal., errors in the anal., and relevant issues to be verified. A validation report is generated in the form of a list of ALERTS on the issues to be cor., checked, or commented on. Structure validation has largely eliminated obvious problems with structure reports published in IUCr journals, such as refinement in a space group of too low symmetry. This paper reports on the current status of structure validation and possible future extensions.

        Fast capture and separation of, and luminescent probe for, pollutant chromate using a multi-functional cationic heterometal-organic framework
        Shi, Peng-Fei; Zhao, Bin; Xiong, Gang; Hou, Yin-Ling; Cheng, Peng

Addnl., 1-ClO4 exhibits interesting slow magnetic relaxation behavior at low temp.

        Zeng, Y.; Woo, H.; Lee, G.; Park, J. Microporous Mesoporous Mater. 2010, 130, 83– 91
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        25
        Adsorption of Cr(VI) on hexadecylpyridinium bromide (HDPB) modified natural zeolites
        Zeng, Yubin; Woo, Heesoo; Lee, Gwanghun; Park, Junboum
        Microporous and Mesoporous Materials (2010), 130 (1-3), 83-91CODEN: MIMMFJ; ISSN:1387-1811. (Elsevier Inc.)
        Adsorption of Cr(VI) on Pohang zeolite (PZ) and Haruna zeolite (HZ) modified with surfactant hexadecylpyridinium bromide (HDPB) was investigated by batch studies, x-ray diffraction (XRD), FT-IR spectroscopy, and SEM analyses. Cr(VI) adsorption on HDPB-zeolites have quick initial speed and adsorption kinetics follow pseudo-second order kinetic model within the initial adsorption stage. HDPB-zeolites have higher affinities toward chromate than that to natural zeolites, and particularly, HDPB-HZ exhibits the highest adsorption capacity in the all samples studied. Addnl., the adsorption of Cr(VI) on HDPB-PZ is almost const. in a wide pH range 3.0-11.0 of soln. In contrast, the Cr(VI)-uptake for HDPB-HZ strongly depends on the soln. pH. The highest Cr(VI) adsorption on HDPB-HZ occurs in acidic solns. (pH 3.0-5.0) and the amt. of sorbed Cr(VI) decreases rapidly with increasing pH. High soln. ionic strength has a significant effect on chromate adsorption. The chromate adsorptions by HDPB-zeolites are not affected by coexisting Cl-, NO3-, SO42-, and Ca2+ as well as Mg2+ but are reduced drastically in the presence of bicarbonate and phosphate. Moreover, HDPB-zeolites can achieve high regeneration efficiency after using N2CO3 extn. and HCl. The analyses of XRD, FTIR, and SEM reveal that HDPB cations are incorporated into the zeolite's structure via ion-exchange and van der Waals forces. Anion exchange and electrostatic interaction are probably the main mechanisms that govern the Cr(VI) adsorption.

        (a) Das, S. K.; Mukherjee, M.; Guha, A. K. Langmuir 2008, 24, 8643– 8650
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        26a
        Interaction of Chromium with Resistant Strain Aspergillus versicolor: Investigation with Atomic Force Microscopy and Other Physical Studies
        Das, Sujoy K.; Mukherjee, Manabendra; Guha, Arun K.
        Langmuir (2008), 24 (16), 8643-8650CODEN: LANGD5; ISSN:0743-7463. (American Chemical Society)
        The interaction of chromium and a chromate resistant Aspergillus versicolor strain has been studied by at. force (AFM) and transmission electron (TEM) microscopies. The nanomech. properties such as cell wall rigidity and elasticity were measured by force spectroscopy and 0.61±0.08 N/m, and 20.5±2.1 MPa, resp. On chromium binding, ultrastructural changes of the cell wall along with the formation of layered structures on the cell wall were obsd. TEM and AFM micrographs demonstrate the accumulation of chromium on the cell wall, which were rough and irregular compared with the smooth pristine mycelia. The surface roughness, cell wall rigidity and elasticity increased to 35.5±3.5 nm, 0.88±0.05 N/m, and 62.5±3.5 MPa, resp., from the corresponding values of 5.2±0.68 nm, 0.61±0.02 N/m, and 20.5±2.1 MPa for the pristine mycelia. XPS and Fourier transform IR studies suggest that bound chromium was reduced to its trivalent state by the cell wall components. The reduced chromium species on the cell surface further electrostatically bind chromate ions forming layered structure on the cell wall.

        (b) Pathak, A. K.; Mukherjee, T.; Maity, D. K. J. Phys. Chem. A 2008, 112, 3399– 3408
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        26b
        Microhydration of NO3-: A Theoretical Study on Structure, Stability and IR Spectra
        Pathak, A. K.; Mukherjee, T.; Maity, D. K.
        Journal of Physical Chemistry A (2008), 112 (15), 3399-3408CODEN: JPCAFH; ISSN:1089-5639. (American Chemical Society)
        A systematic study on the structure and stability of nitrate anion hydrated clusters, NO3-·nH2O (n = 1-8) were carried out using the DFT-B3LYP method. Several possible initial structures are considered for each size cluster to locate equil. geometry by applying a correlated hybrid d. functional with 6-311++G(d,p) basis function. Three different types of arrangements, namely, sym. double hydrogen bonding, single hydrogen bonding and inter-water hydrogen bonding are obtained in these hydrated clusters. A structure having inter-water hydrogen bonding is more stable compared to other arrangements. Surface structures are predicted to be more stable over interior structures. Up to five solvent H2O mols. can stay around solute NO3- anion in structures having an inter-water hydrogen-bonded cyclic network. A linear correlation is obtained for weighted av. solvent stabilization energy with the size (n) of the hydrated cluster. Distinctly different shifts of IR bands are obsd. in these hydrated clusters for different kinds of bonding environments of O-H and N=O stretching modes compared to isolated H2O and NO3- anion. Weighted av. IR spectra are calcd. on the basis of statistical population of individual configurations of each size cluster at 150 K.
